facts.text: This appeal is Civil Appeal No. 2208 of 1972 by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 3rd April, 1972 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 325 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2208 of 1972.  Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 3rd April, 1972 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 325 of 1970 .

facts.text: The appellant filed a suit to recover possession of certain premises from the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, arises out of a suit filed by the appellant to recover possession of certain premises from the respondents.

facts.text: The appellant is the owner of two bungalows in Navsari, Truth Bungalow and Hill Bungalow.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the owner of two bungalows in Navsari, a town situate in South Gujarat. One bungalow is known by the name of Truth Bungalow while the other is known by the name of Hill Bungalow.

facts.text: The separate room on the ground floor of the Truth Bungalow was at all material times in the possession of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It was common ground between the parties and that appears clearly from the evidence and has also been found by the High Court as well as the lower courts, that this separate room on the ground floor of the Truth Bungalow was at all material times in the possession of the appellant.

facts.text: The rest of the Truth Bungalow was let out to a tenant some two and a half to three years prior to the recording of the evidence, but after a period of about one year and a quarter the tenant surrendered possession.

anchor.surface_text: The rest of the Truth Bungalow was, some two and a half to three years prior to the recording of the evidence, let out to a tenant, but after a period of about one year and a quarter the tenant surrendered possession and thereafter it was

facts.text: The appellant gave the Truth Bungalow to Dr. Bharucha on leave and licence on payment of compensation of Rs. 50/- per month in January 1966 or January 1967.

anchor.surface_text: given by the appellant to one Dr. Bharucha on leave and licence on payment of compensation of Rs. 50/- per month. The appellant in his evidence could not state precisely when this leave and licence was granted by him. He said that it was given in January 1966 or it may be in January 1967.

facts.text: Dr. Bharucha was in occupation of the Truth Bungalow, barring the ground floor room, from January 1967 on leave and licence from the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Bharucha was thus in occupation of the Truth Bungalow, barring the ground floor room in the possession of the appellant, from January 1967 on leave and licence from the appellant.

facts.text: The Hill Bungalow consists of two tenements, one on the ground floor and the other on the first floor.

anchor.surface_text: The Hill Bungalow consists of two tenanments, one on the ground floor and the other on the first floor.

facts.text: The first floor of Hill Bungalow is occupied by Soonabai, the mother of the appellant, since the last several years.

anchor.surface_text: The first floor is occupied by Soonabai, the mother of the appellant since the last several years. She is an old lady, aged about 82 years at the time of giving evidence

facts.text: Soonabai was paying a sum of Rs. 50/- per month to the appellant for the occupation of the first floor.

anchor.surface_text: namely, that Soonabai was paying a sum of Rs. 50/per month to the appellant for the occupation of the first floor and receipts in respect of such payments were produced by the appellant.

facts.text: The ground floor of the Hill Bungalow was let out by the appellant to Mahendra Prasad in 1957 at a rent of Rs. 65/- per month.

anchor.surface_text: The ground floor of the Hill Bungalow was let out by the appellant to one Mahendra Prasad as far back as 1957 it a rent of Rs. 65/- per month.

facts.text: Mahendra Prasad died in September 1966 leaving surviving his widow the fifth respondent, his son the first respondent and his daughter the second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Mahendra Prasad died in September 1966 leaving him surviving as his legal representatives his widow the fifth respondent. his son the first respondent and his. daughter the second respondent.

facts.text: Respondents 3 and 4 together with members of their families came to reside in the ground floor premises sometime prior to the death of Mahendra Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime prior to the death of Mahendra Prasad, respondents 3 and 4 together with the members of their respective families had come to reside in the ground floor premises

facts.text: After Mahendra Prasad's death, respondents 3 and 4 continued to stay with the first respondent in the ground floor premises.

anchor.surface_text: and after the death of Mahendra Prasad, they continued to stay with the first respondent. The second and the fifth respondents, however, left the ground floor premises

facts.text: The second and fifth respondents left the ground floor premises soon after Mahendra Prasad's death.

anchor.surface_text: The second and the fifth respondents, however, left the ground floor premises and went away from Navsari soon after the death of Mahendra Prasad.

facts.text: Appellant issued notice dated 15th October 1966 terminating tenancy of respondents 1,2,5 for unlawful sub-letting to 3 and 4.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, by a notice dated 15th October, 1966, terminated the tenancy of respondents 1, 2 and 5 on the ground that they had unlawfully sub-let the ground floor premises to respondents 3 and 4.

facts.text: Appellant filed Regular Suit No. 26 of 1967 in the Court of Civil Judge, Senior Division, Navsari on 18th January 1967 for possession on ground of unlawful sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was constrained to file regular suit No. 26 of 1967 in the court of the ,Civil Judge, Senior Division, Navsari on 18th January 1967.

facts.text: Appellant amended the plaint introducing ground of reasonable and bona fide requirement for personal use under s.13(1)(g) of Bombay Rent Act.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant, therefore, with the leave of the Court, amended the plaint in that suit introducing an additional ground that the appellant reasonably and bona fide required the ground floor premises for his personal use and occupation

facts.text: Trial court held no unlawful sub-letting proved but bona fide need and no greater hardship to tenants, passed decree for eviction.

anchor.surface_text: the trial court, on consideration of the evidence led on behalf of the appellant and respondents 1, 3 and 4, took the view that, though respondents 3 and 4 together with the members of their respective families were residing in the ground floor premises with the first respondent, it was not established by the appellant that they were subtenants

facts.text: District Judge, Bulsar confirmed the decree for eviction and dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge, who heard the appeal, found himself in complete agreement with the conclusions reached by the trial court and he accordingly confirmed the decree for eviction and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court in revision set aside decree, holding no bona fide need and greater hardship to tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in revision interfered with the findings of the District Judge on both the questions, namely, reasonable and bona fide requirement for persona use and occupation as also greater hardship

facts.text: Appellant retired from Army service in 1960 and carried on profession as architect and consulting engineer in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was carrying on his Profession as architect and consulting engineer in Bombay since 1960 when he retired from Army service.

facts.text: Appellant lived in a flat in Bombay paying rent of Rs. 475/- per month.

anchor.surface_text: He lived in a flat in Bombay for which he paid a rent of Rs. 475/- per month.

facts.text: By middle of 1968, appellant's work in Bombay dwindled to nil and professional activities confined to South Gujarat.

anchor.surface_text: The principal area of work in the early stages of his professional career was Bombay and South Gujarat but by about the middle of 1968 his work in Bombay practically dwindled to nil and his professional activities became confined almost exclusively to South Gujarat.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment, restored decree for eviction.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, clear that the High Court was in error in setting aside the decree for eviction passed against the respondents. We would accordingly allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court and restore the decree for eviction passed against the respondents.
Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 3rd April, 1972 of the Gujarat High Court in Civil Revision

issues.text: What is the true scope and ambit of the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 29, sub-s. 3 of the Bombay Rent Act?

anchor.surface_text: The main ground on which the appellant attacked the judgment of the High Court was that in reversing the findings of the District Judge on the question of reasonable and bona fide requirement for personal use and occupation as also on the question of greater hardship, the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction under s. 29, subs.  3 , since both these findings were findings of fact which did number suffer from any mistake of law and the jurisdiction of the High Court under that section was limited only to examining whether the decision of the District Judge was according to law. Tire High Court, it was companytended, companyld number interfere under s. 29, sub-s.  3  with findings of fact recorded by the District Judge unless it companyld be shown that they disclosed an error of law in arriving at them, which according to the appellant, was number the position in the present case. This companytention raises a question as to the true scope and ambit of the revisional jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 29, sub-s.  3 .

issues.text: Whether the High Court exceeded its revisional jurisdiction under s.29(3) by interfering with the District Judge's finding that the appellant reasonably and bona fide required the ground floor premises for his own use and occupation under s.13(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: true meaning of the word requires in S. 13  1   g  and interpreted it companyrectly, to mean that there in an element of need before a landlord can be said to require premises for his own use and occupation. It is number enough that the landlord should merely desire to use and occupy the premises. What is necessary is that he should need them for his own use and occupation. This was the companyrect test applied by the District Judge to the facts found by him.

issues.text: Whether the High Court exceeded its revisional jurisdiction under s.29(3) by interfering with the District Judge's finding on greater hardship under s.13(2)?

anchor.surface_text: So far as the finding on the question of greater hardship is companycerned, the District Judge decided against the respondents on the view that as soon as the landlord establishes that he reasonably and bonafide requires the premises for his own use and occupation, the burden of proving that greater hardship would be caused by passing a decree for eviction than by refusing to pass it is on the tenant

issues.text: Whether the appellant reasonably and bona fide required the ground floor premises for his own use and occupation under s.13(1)(g)?

anchor.surface_text: Taking up first for companysideration the finding that the appellant reasonably and bona fide required the ground floor premises for his own use and occupation, it may be pointed out straight 8 way that this finding was clearly one of fact. The District Judge did number misdirect himself in regard to the true meaning of the word requires in S. 13  1   g

issues.text: Whether greater hardship would be caused to the respondents by passing a decree for eviction than to the appellant by refusing it under s.13(2)?

anchor.surface_text: relation to s. 13 2  of the Bombay Rent Act, which is in identical terms We do number find ourselves able to accept the broad proposition that as soon as the landlord establishes his need for additional accommodation he is relieved of all further obligation under s. 21 sub-s.  4  and that once the landlords need is accepted by the companyrt all further evidence must be adduced by the tenant

anchor.surface_text: terminated the tenancy of respondents 1, 2 and 5 on the ground that they had unlawfully sub-let the ground floor premises to respondents 3 and 4. Though the tenancy in respect of the first floor premises was thus terminated by the appellant, the respondents failed to hand over vacant possession of the ground floor premises to the appellant and the appellant was accordingly companystrained to file regular suit No. 26 of 1967

arguments.claim: High Court exceeded its revisional jurisdiction under s.29(3) Bombay Rent Act by interfering with concurrent findings of fact on reasonable and bona fide requirement and greater hardship, as no mistake of law.

anchor.surface_text: The main ground on which the appellant attacked the judgment of the High Court was that in reversing the findings of the District Judge on the question of reasonable and bona fide requirement for personal use and occupation as also on the question of greater hardship, the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction under s. 29, subs.  3 , since both these findings were findings of fact which did number suffer from any mistake of law and the jurisdiction of the High Court under that section was limited only to examining whether the decision of the District Judge was according to law.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nt for personal use and occupation as also on the question of greater hardship, the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction under s. 29, subs.  3 , since

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepted for bona fide need (pure fact finding, correct test applied); rejected for hardship (District Judge erred on burden of proof).

arguments.claim: Revisional jurisdiction under s.29(3) limited to miscarriage of justice due to mistake of law; cannot reappreciate evidence or substitute factual findings.

anchor.surface_text: Fortunately this question is number devoid of authority. There are sections in other rent companytrol legislations companyched in identical language and they have received judicial interpretation at the hands of this Court. The first decision to which we may refer in this companynection is Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdharilal Chaudhury 1 .

arguments.claim: District Judge's finding on bona fide need under s.13(1)(g) is pure fact; applied correct test ('requires' means need, not desire); High Court cannot interfere by reappreciating evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Taking up first for companysideration the finding that the appellant reasonably and bona fide required the ground floor premises for his own use and occupation, it may be pointed out straight 8 way that this finding was clearly one of fact. The District Judge did number misdirect himself in regard to the true meaning of the word requires in S. 13  1   g  and interpreted it companyrectly, to mean that there in an element of need before a landlord can be said to require premises for his own use and occupation.

arguments.claim: High Court erred on merits of bona fide need: Soonabai is tenant (rent receipts > oral 'compensation' statement); first floor not available for family; Truth Bungalow not available (licensee occupation requires termination); no other suitable space.

anchor.surface_text: If he had applied a wrong test on a misconstruction of the word requires, the finding recorded by him would have been vitiated by an error of law. But the companyrect test having been applied, the finding of the, District Judge that the appellant reasonably and bona fide required the ground floor premises for his own use and occupation was unquestionably a finding of fact and it was number companypete it to the High Court, in the exercise of its revisional power under s. 29, sub-s.  3 , to interfere with this finding by reappreciating the evidence.

arguments.claim: Once landlord proves bona fide need under s.13(1)(g), burden shifts to tenant to prove greater hardship under s.13(2).

anchor.surface_text: So far as the finding on the question of greater hardship is companycerned, the District Judge decided against the respondents on the view that as soon as the landlord establishes that he reasonably and bonafide requires the premises for his own use and occupation, the burden of proving that greater hardship would be caused by passing a decree for eviction than by refusing to pass it is on the tenant

arguments.court_reasoning: Both parties must adduce evidence on comparative hardship; cites Central Tobacco Co. rejecting burden shift.

arguments.claim: Under s.13(2), both landlord and tenant must prove comparative hardship; no automatic burden shift after need proved.

anchor.surface_text: This Court speaking through Mitter, J., pointed out in that case, while discussing S. 21 4  of the Mysore Rent Control Act 1961, and what was said there must apply equally in relation to s. 13 2  of the Bombay Rent Act, which is in identical terms We do number find ourselves able to accept the broad proposition that as soon as the landlord establishes his need for additional accommodation he is relieved of all further obligation under s. 21 sub-s.  4

arguments.claim: Evidence shows no greater hardship to tenant; landlord would suffer financial/professional hardship (Bombay rent high, work in S. Gujarat); no tenant evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence was entirely the other way. The appellant stated in his evidence that he would suffer companysiderable hardship both financial and in the way of his profession if he was denied possession of the ground floor premises. This was true because the entire field of work of the appellant was number companyfined to South Gujarat

Though the tenancy in respect of the first floor premises was thus terminated by the appellant, the respondents failed to hand over vacant possession

arguments.court_reasoning: Concurrent findings of lower courts restored; HC erred.

The High Court then proceeded to companysider the availability of the Truth Bungalow... since... given on leave and licence... in the possession of the appellant.

arguments.court_reasoning: Soonabai tenant per receipts; Truth not available without terminating licence; no suitable room.

arguments.claim: Greater hardship to tenant than landlord under s.13(2).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in revision interfered... held... that... greater hardship would be caused to the first respondent by passing a decree for eviction than by refusing to pass it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Court speaking through Mitter, J., pointed out in that case, while discussing S. 21 4  of the Mysore Rent Control Act 1961, and what was said there m

arguments.court_reasoning: No evidence for tenant hardship; landlord evidence uncontroverted.

holdings.text: The High Court can interfere with the decision of the lower court under s. 29, sub-s. 3 only if there is miscarriage of justice due to a mistake of law. The High Court cannot reassess the value of the evidence and interfere with a finding of fact merely because it thinks that the appreciation of the evidence by the lower court is wrong.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court can, therefore, interfere with the decision of the lower court under s. 29, sub-s. 3 only if there is miscarriage of justice due, to a mistake of law. The High Court cannot reassess the value of the evidence and interfere with a finding of fact merely because it thinks that the appreciation of the evidence by the lower

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets s.29(3) following precedents on identical provisions in other rent acts (Hari Shankar, Puranchand); limits to legal errors, not fact reappreciation.

holdings.text: The finding that the appellant reasonably and bona fide required the ground floor premises for his own use and occupation under s.13(1)(g) is a pure finding of fact based on correct test ('requires' means need, not desire); High Court exceeded jurisdiction by reappreciating evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Taking up first for consideration the finding that the appellant reasonably and bona fide required the ground floor premises for his own use and occupation, it may be pointed out straight 8 way that this finding was clearly one of fact. The District Judge did not misdirect himself in regard to the true meaning of the word requires in S. 13

holdings.reasoning_summary: District Judge applied correct legal test; no misdirection; HC cannot substitute factual findings in revision.

holdings.text: Appellant reasonably and bona fide requires ground floor under s.13(1)(g): first floor occupied by tenant-mother Soonabai (rent receipts prevail over oral 'compensation'); Truth Bungalow not available (licensee Dr. Bharucha in occupation, requires termination); garage unsuitable.

anchor.surface_text: If he had applied a wrong test on a misconstruction of the word requires, the finding recorded by him would have been vitiated by an error of law. But the correct test having been applied, the finding of the, District Judge that the appellant reasonably and bona fide required the ground floor premises for his own use and occupation was unquestionably a finding of fact

holdings.reasoning_summary: Credits documentary evidence (receipts) over oral statement; distinguishes juridical possession from availability for occupation in licensee cases; no suitable alternatives.

holdings.text: District Judge erred in law on s.13(2) greater hardship by wrongly placing entire burden on tenant after landlord proves need; both parties must adduce evidence on comparative hardship.

anchor.surface_text: This Court speaking through Mitter, J., pointed out in that case, while discussing S. 21 4 of the Mysore Rent Control Act 1961, and what was said there must apply equally in relation to s. 13 2 of the Bombay Rent Act, which is in identical terms We do not find ourselves able to accept the broad proposition that as soon as the landlord establishes his need for additional accommodation he is relieved of all further obligation under s. 21 sub-s.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Central Tobacco Co. (Mysore Act analogous); rejects burden shift; both must prove hardship caused by grant/refusal.

holdings.text: No greater hardship to tenant under s.13(2): landlord would suffer financial/professional hardship (high Bombay rent, work in S.Gujarat); no evidence of tenant hardship.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence was entirely the other way. The appellant stated in his evidence that he would suffer considerable hardship both financial and in the way of his profession if he was denied possession of the ground floor premises. This was true because the entire field of work of the appellant was not confined to South Gujarat

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence one-sided favoring landlord; uncontroverted; applies correct burden to facts.

holdings.text: No unlawful sub-letting under s.13(1)(e): respondents 3&4 residing as family members with first respondent, not proved as subtenants.

anchor.surface_text: the trial court, on consideration of the evidence led on behalf of the appellant and respondents 1, 3 and 4, took the view that, though respondents 3 and 4 together with the members of their respective families were residing in the ground floor premises with the first respondent, it was not established by the appellant that they were subtenants

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts lower courts' concurrent factual finding; no further discussion needed.

holdings.text: Soonabai is tenant of first floor (rent receipts), not licensee; oral 'compensation' statement by layman insufficient against documents.

anchor.surface_text: There was here documentary evidence in the shape of rent receipt as against oral imperfectly understood admission made by the appellant, which supported the view taken by the District Judge that Soonabai was a tenant and not a licencee of the appellant and the High Court was in error in upsetting this view taken by the District Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documentary evidence prevails over oral admission by non-expert.

holdings.text: Leave and licence does not make premises available without terminating licence; licensor in juridical possession but occupant must vacate for availability.

anchor.surface_text: But for the purpose of determining whether the requirement of the appellant for the ground floor premises was reasonable and bonafide, what is necessary to be considered is not whether the appellant was juridically in possession of the Truth Bungalow, but whether the Truth Bungalow was available to the appellant for occupation so that he could not be said to need the ground floor premises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes juridical possession from practical availability under bona fide need test.

precedents.citation: Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdharilal Chaudhury 1

anchor.surface_text: The first decision to which we may refer in this companynection is Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdharilal Chaudhury 1 . The section which fell for companysideration in this case was s. 35, sub-s. 1 of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952 which was in the same terms as s. 29, sub-s. 3 of our Act. Explaining the seeps of S. 35, sub-s. 1 in the companytext of s. 34, Hidayatullah, J.,

precedents.case_name: Hari Shankar v. Rao Girdharilal Chaudhury
precedents.cited_proposition: Scope of revisional jurisdiction under s.35(1) of Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act (identical to s.29(3) of Bombay Rent Act): High Court may interfere only if decision not according to law i.e. miscarriage of justice due to mistake of law, not to re-appreciate evidence or substitute findings of fact
precedents.cited_holding: Section 35 follows s. 34... The phrase according to law refers to the decision as a whole... miscarriage of justice due to a mistake of law.

precedents.citation: Bell Co. Ltd. v. Waman Hemraj 1

anchor.surface_text: Then the learned Judge quoted in extensor the following observations of Beaumont, C.J., in Bell Co. Ltd. v. Waman Hemraj 1  in relation to s. 25 of the Provincial Small Causes Courts Act which was almost in the same terms as s. 35, sub-section  1  The object of s. 25 is to enable the High Court to see that there has been numbermiscarriage of justice, that the decision was given according to law.

precedents.case_name: Bell Co. Ltd. v. Waman Hemraj
precedents.cited_proposition: Scope of revision under s.25 Provincial Small Causes Courts Act (similar terms): interfere if no proper trial according to law, no miscarriage of justice, not merely because High Court would reach different conclusion
precedents.cited_holding: The object of s. 25 is to enable the High Court to see that there has been numbermiscarriage of justice, that the decision was given according to law.

anchor.surface_text: This view was reaffirmed by Subba Rao, J.,  as he then was  speaking on behalf of this Court in Puranchand v. Motilal  2  , where the same section 35, sub-s.  1  of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act again came up for companysideration. The scheme and language of s. 29, sub-s.  3  of our Act being identical with that of s. 35, sub-s.  1  of the Delhi and Ajmer Rent Control Act, 1952, the same view must also govern the interpretation of s. 29, sub-s.  3  of our Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: Reaffirmation of scope of revisional jurisdiction under s.35(1) Delhi Act: same as Hari Shankar

anchor.surface_text: This view in regard to the burden of proof, numberdoubt, prevailed at one time in various High Courts on the basis of the decision of the Court of Appeal in England in Kelly v. Goodwin 1  but it can numberlonger be regarded as companyrect after the, decision of this Court in M s. Central Tobacco Co. v. Chandra Prakash 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Once landlord establishes reasonable and bona fide requirement, burden shifts to tenant to prove greater hardship

precedents.citation: M s. Central Tobacco Co. v. Chandra Prakash 2

anchor.surface_text: but it can numberlonger be regarded as companyrect after the, decision of this Court in M s. Central Tobacco Co. v. Chandra Prakash 2 . This Court speaking through Mitter, J., pointed out in that case, while discussing S. 21 4  of the Mysore Rent Control Act 1961, and what was said there must apply equally in relation to s. 13 2  of the Bombay Rent Act, which is in identical terms We do number find ourselves able to accept the broad proposition that as soon as the landlord establishes his need for additional accommodation he is relieved of all further obligation under s. 21 sub-s.  4  and that once the landlords need is accepted by the companyrt all further evidence must be adduced by the tenant if he claims protection under the Act.

precedents.case_name: M/s Central Tobacco Co. v. Chandra Prakash
precedents.cited_proposition: On greater hardship under rent control eviction grounds: both landlord and tenant must adduce evidence on respective hardships; burden does not entirely shift to tenant after proving need; court decides after considering all evidence
precedents.cited_holding: Each party must adduce evidence to show what hardship would be caused to him... It is only after shifting such evidence that the companyrt must form its companyclusion...
